title: PROGRAM 3: SLEEP OPTIMIZATION
subtitle: Weeks 1-4: Advanced Sleep Architecture
subtitleDescription: This advanced phase focuses on optimizing your sleep cycles and understanding your personal chronotype. You'll learn to work with your body's natural rhythms rather than against them, using data tracking and environmental optimization to achieve peak sleep quality.
videoDescription: Dive deep into sleep cycles, REM stages, and how to optimize each phase for maximum restoration. Learn to track and interpret your sleep data to make informed adjustments.
description: Building on your established sleep foundation, this program takes you into advanced sleep optimization. You'll learn about sleep architecture, chronotypes, and how to use sophisticated tracking to fine-tune your sleep environment and routine. This is for those who have mastered the basics and are ready to achieve elite-level sleep quality.

sections.title: Phase Goals
items: Identify your personal chronotype (early bird, night owl, or hummingbird)
Optimize sleep cycles to wake during light sleep phases
Master advanced environmental controls (temperature, light, sound)

children: Use sleep tracker or app (Oura Ring, Whoop, Apple Watch, or Sleep Cycle app)
Track these metrics daily:
Total sleep time
REM sleep percentage (target: 20-25%)
Deep sleep percentage (target: 15-20%)
Sleep efficiency (time asleep vs. time in bed)
Heart rate variability (HRV) during sleep
Wake-up count and timing
Set bedroom to 65-68¬∞F (18-20¬∞C)
Use cooling mattress pad or weighted blanket
Cool room 1 hour before bed
Warmest point: 2-3 hours before wake time
Gradual warming triggers natural wake-up
Take warm shower 90 minutes before bed (helps core temp drop)
Morning: Get 10+ minutes bright light within 30 min of waking
Afternoon: Maintain bright environment until 6 PM
Evening: Dim lights 2-3 hours before bed
Activate device blue light filters at sunset
Use amber/red lights in evening
Consider blue-blocking glasses after 8 PM
Blackout curtains or eye mask for sleeping
Take chronotype quiz (search "Chronotype Quiz Michael Breus")
Lion (Early Bird): Natural wake 5:30-6 AM, peak 8 AM-12 PM
Bear (Most Common): Natural wake 7-8 AM, peak 10 AM-2 PM
Wolf (Night Owl): Natural wake 7:30-9 AM, peak 5-9 PM
Dolphin (Light Sleeper): Irregular, peak varies
Adjust schedule ¬±1 hour toward your natural chronotype
Schedule important tasks during your peak performance windows
Identify noise disruptions using tracker
White noise machine or app (40-50 dB)
Earplugs if needed (32 NRR rating)
Pink noise for deeper sleep (lower frequencies than white)
Binaural beats during wind-down (delta waves 0.5-4 Hz)
Avoid alcohol 4+ hours before bed (disrupts REM)
Keep room temperature stable (prevents wake-ups)
Keep journal by bed
Write dreams immediately upon waking
Note patterns and themes
Indicates healthy REM cycles
Target 90-minute sleep cycles (plan wake time accordingly)
Use smart alarm that wakes during light sleep phase
Set 30-minute wake window (e.g., 6:30-7:00 AM)
Gradual light alarm (sunrise simulation)
Avoid snoozing - disrupts sleep cycles

sections.title: Daily Tracking Goals for Weeks 1-4
items: Weekly review: Compare data to identify patterns
Adjust one variable per week based on data

sections.title: Success Markers
items: Wake feeling refreshed 5+ days per week
Can fall back asleep within 20 min if waking at night

closingNote: Advanced Sleep Science: Your brain cycles through 90-minute sleep stages (light ‚Üí deep ‚Üí REM) 4-6 times per night. Deep sleep (physical recovery) dominates the first half of night, while REM sleep (mental recovery, memory consolidation) dominates the second half. By optimizing your environment and timing, you can maximize both. Elite athletes and performers treat sleep like training - you're now doing the same.
